results.name: Steps saved by choice in "3x+1" iteration.
comment: Normal "3x+1" iteration requires x->x/2 if x is even. a(n) is the number of iterations that can be saved by also allowing x->3x+1 if x is even.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000 (computed from the b-files of A006577 and A127885)
example: a(9) = 8 because for 9 the traditional 3x+1 iteration follows the 19-step path:
while allowing x->3x+1 for even x gives the 11-step path:
mathematica: Table[Length@ NestWhileList[If[OddQ@ #, 3 # + 1, #/2] &, n, # > 1 &] - Length@ NestWhileList[Flatten[# /. {k_ /; OddQ@ k :> 3 k + 1, k_ /; EvenQ@ k :> {k/2, 3 k + 1}}] &, {n}, FreeQ[#, 1] &], {n, 126}] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Aug 20 2017 *)
xref: Cf. A006577, A127885, A127887 (gives the indices of the nonzero entries).
